captions.text:
In 1965 Singapore gained its independence
from Malaysia. Since then, the tiny island

city-state has been industrializing and growing
at an unprecedented rate. This year, they

were voted the most expensive city in the
world for the second year running. So we wanted
to know, how powerful is Singapore?

Well, for starters, Singapore is a tiny island
in Southeast Asia, with a population of a

little over 5 million packed into 277 square
miles. That’s roughly if everyone in Minnesota

squeezed into an area the size of San Francisco.
Along with South Korea, Taiwan, and Hong Kong,

Singapore is one of the Four Asian Tigers;
nations that have experienced significant

growth since the 1960s and have high-income
economies. Their GDP is nearly $300 billion

dollars. And they are 9th in the world in
terms of per-capita GDP, although overall

they rank 37th in the global economy. One
of the primary reasons for Singapore’s wealth

is that they operate the largest, and busiest,
transshipment port in the world.

In short, Singapore is rich. So what are they
spending their money on? Well, mostly defense

and guns. According to the Stockholm International
Peace Research Institute Singapore is the

5th largest arms importer in the world, after
China, India, Pakistan and South Korea. They

spent a quarter of their yearly budget, on
defense in 2012. By comparison the US spends

about a fifth of their budget on the same.
As a result, Singapore has a formidable military

force. In particular, the Singaporean Royal
Air Force is the largest, best trained, and
most equipped flying force in Southeast Asia.

Singapore also has mandatory two-year conscription
of all 18-year-old males. Meaning that Singapore

sits on more than a million reserve troops,
should they ever need them. As a result of

this military stockpiling, Singapore has a
very close relationship with the United States.

In fact, the US is the primary buyer of Singaporean
military equipment, making up 43% of their
total sales.

Singapore also enjoys friendly, diplomatic
relationships with most of the developed Western

world, with the exception of their neighbor,
Malaysia. This primarily stems from Indonesia

having been expelled from Malaysian rule in
1965 over policy disputes, and later, disagreements

over land ownership in the South China Sea.
However the two countries rely on each other

heavily for trade, and in recent years have
largely resolved their issues through new
leadership.

With a huge cash surplus, tremendous military
and close relations with the United States,

Singapore might not be a traditional international
behemoth in regards to land size. But it certainly

stands on its own as one of the best equipped
and most powerful countries in Southeast Asia.

To find out just what makes Singapore so expensive,
check out our video here. If you’re on your

phone, there’s a link to that video right
at the top of the description, so check it

out! Thanks for watching TestTube! Please
subscribe for all our daily videos.

comments.text:
A true powerhouse because she caters to both the rich and the poor. Her 
citizens and foreigners have stakes in this beautiful island. Which country 
is able to implement COE (certificate of entitlement) to buy a car without 
causing an uproar? Singaporeans are happy to pay because they know the 
money go back to them in the form of better infrastructure and amenities. 
Singapore and Singaporeans have for decades uplifted the lives of her Asian 
neighbours in terms of jobs, mission aid, grants and donations. Malaysians, 
our close neighbours have always top the foreign workforce in Singapore. 
The most touching expression of the beneficiaries' gratitude is the honour 
bestowed on our wise founder, Mr Lee Kuan Yew.﻿ ﻿

comments.author: Ozymandias “the” King

comments.text:
+Ozymandias King Thank you very much for your royal comments about 
Singapore. You can say we are 'cool as cucumbers' because of all of Mr 
Lee's policies.. even those on the fence. It is either breaching the spirit 
of a few individuals or that of a whole nation. From experience, we know he 
cared enough to give us the best of everything - both tangible and 
intangible.
comments.author: Florenz Yap

comments.text:
+iloveursis 
1. Yeah, expensive housing in a place where the unemployment rate is 
literally 1.9% from a 2013 estimate. In a city-state that's comparable to 
New York or LA. Have you been to LA or New York? They have the exact same 
problem as Singapore, which is a byproduct of having a nation with high 
education and high commerce. Not even including subsidized housing, which 
makes this a non-problem. Besides, why this and your non-problem of "high 
minister salaries" are not as big of issues as you make it out to be is....

2. Its economic policies WORK. Who gives a shit that the minister is paid a 
lot? That has very little effect on the economy. DESPITE this, Lee Hsien 
Loong took a 36% paycut (
http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2082124/Lee-Hsien-Loong-Singapores-Prime-Minister-earn-1-7m-36-pay-cut.html). 
And the news is very misleading. While the base salaries of these people 
are higher than that of Obama or other first world leaders, lobby money and 
commission account for far more of Obama's salary than Lee Hsein Loong. At 
least he's transparent. 

Furthermore, this cements the idea that your MERIT determines your worth in 
the workforce. The average income of a Singaporean is $57,000 US dollars (
http://www.financialsamurai.com/how-much-money-do-the-top-income-earners-make-percent/), 
rounded a bit. It's actually a few hundred dollars higher. See the source. 
Furthermore, the government still supplements the income of low skilled 
workers so they can still live fairly well off compared to migrant workers 
and low skilled workers in other first world nations. Income disparity is 
not always indicative of poverty, though there is a strong correlation. 

Remember, also, that there are trade and labor unions all throughout the 
nation. 

3. Until you've been to the subways of New York, you have no right to say 
that Singapore's train system sucks. No train system ever works 100% of the 
time but I've heard nothing but good things about Singapore from tourists 
and residents. As for transport fares, it's again, a byproduct of living in 
a city the size of New York, give or take. 

4. The mandatory conscription that you say is, "cheap singaporean male 
labor," is present all throughout Asia. While I disagree with the idea of 
giving up higher education for 2 years to be forced to train for a few 
months and stand around with your thumb up your ass, it's not some uncommon 
totalitarian policy. Furthermore, remember that nations such as the US do 
not have this policy because they don't have neighbors that could invade 
them at any time or terrorist cells in nations right next to Singapore. 
That's why South Korea has this policy as well, despite being a democratic 
nation. 

5. Cheap labor isn't gotten from Singapore by gagging Malaysians and 
importing them through the black market. They're gained because Malaysians 
WANT to work. Singapore has a surplus of jobs in the low skill sector and 
the regional market is there to say, "hey, I want some of that surplus. 
It's low skill so I don't expect pay equivalent to a scientist or 
engineer." And Singapore happily obliges. 

6. In Singapore, I can watch any Youtube video I want, torrent a few 
movies, watch Netflix, and browse any news story I want. I might be put on 
a few lists but in this day and age, what nation on Earth DOESN'T have a 
list? This isn't 1989. No nation can reasonably censor anything anymore 
anyhow. However, I do concede that even the policies that allow Singapore 
to do this existing is a problem but it's becoming less and less of a 
problem. 

7. If I had to characterize Singapore in one word, I would say, 
"Technocracy." Which is cool as shit.
comments.author: Ozymandias “the” King

comments.text:
+Florenz Yap Very true! Mr. Lee Kuan Yew may have had some policies that 
may be on the fence between human rights violation or not but he always had 
a good reason and his policies worked to transform Singapore into the 
powerhouse it is today. Don't forget how incredibly safe the nation is, 
which is unprecedented considering that it's a city with a very high 
population density akin to LA or New York.
comments.author: Ozymandias “the” King

comments.text:
+Nite Achilles If you can deliver, I will gladly pay you top dollars to 
ensure that I can sit back and relax without having to worry about the 
future.
comments.author: Florenz Yap

comments.text:
+iloveursis If you are willing to work hard, there's no need for foreign 
labour. To you it's cheap but to our govt and the labourers it's not. My 
sisters' maid retired at the age of 26 years after working only 8 years for 
her. She sent money home to her parents for them to start a small business. 
She bought 2 plots of land and built 2 houses - one to live in and the 
other to rent out. The Indians too own houses and basic luxuries with the 
money they earn here. They had a send-off for Mr Lee Kuan Yew and passed 
the hat round to start building a museum in his memory. We are also 
grateful to be Singaporeans as evidenced by the recent outpouring of grief 
at the passing of Mr Lee.
comments.author: Florenz Yap

comments.text:
Rich and poor survive happily in Singapore due to the options available. 
Why do you need to live in an expensive private property when ownership of 
a subsidised HDB apartment is available to you at a fraction of the cost? 
Why do you need a car when everywhere is so easily accessible by superfast 
trains from dawn to midnight? Our rail system is maintained regularly. Only 
once in my 8 years of travelling by MRT did I encounter a breakdown. Buses 
were immediately deployed to bring commuters to their destinations. The 
fare increases - of a few cents - are fully justified for the convenience 
and billions spent so far. For 2 years the army boys get free food, lodging 
and allowance while being trained. I enjoy reading the papers and watching 
CNA because of the wide - ranging coverage of world events. Im not 
interested in the other channels so I can't comment. But the few times I 
happen to watch the other Channels, I see local and foreign dramas. As for 
the high ministers' salaries pegged to that of the heads of large 
corporations, I feel it is fair. There is nothing to stop anyone from 
taking over the reins of running this nation but are they capable enough to 
maintain the momentum and even improve on it. If so, I believe Singaporeans 
are matured enough to trust their lives to them. The day 100% love to pay 
and pay for peace and security, you can say it is a police state but 60%? 
40% is under what state?﻿ A police state where I walk around daily in 
freedom to enjoy the order is power in every sense of the word. This is 
what money can't buy!
comments.author: Florenz Yap

comments.text: +iloveursis They love Pay and Pay mah. 60% of them.

comments.text:

50 years, no minimum wage, continuous increase in transport fares,

I for one am not happy to pay. so maybe you're the only one to fit the bill 
of "HAPPY TO PAY SINGAPOEANS"

comments.text:
+Ichu Pichu Wasted? How could you think so? I see that life in NS is tough 
if not tougher. The regimen is as strict as any army training standard. 
Wake up early, hurry u tidy your bed and bunker, fall in. march, jog, swim, 
climb, go fast, GO! GO! GO! GO!. Learn how to carry and handle a rifle. 
take care of it. Treat it better than your wife. How tougher can that go? 
Even some men can't take the heat but nevertheless, most suck it up. 

How can you say that most Singaporean men are thin, nerdy and weak? That's 
just generalizing and making biased judgement. Every country has people of 
different personalities.  When I walk in the streets of S'pore. I see that 
there are many average sized men, some quite slim, others plump, fat or 
obese. Some look tough, muscular, slim and fit, speak loudly[quite rude 
sometimes] or have a brash attitude, many others are normal, some are soft 
spoken or gentlemanly. Nerd? Most people are into tech, gaming, i-Phone, 
Candy Crush, etc, etc. You don't see that stuff as foreign or alien to you, 
do you? How old are you?
